document.description: Toggle Headings are blocks that you can expand. When not extended, only the heading is shown.

<h1>Artes habent</h1>
  

  <p>
    Unam tanti termini quanti termini probo amicitia autem modo ab nos qui
    alteram alteram quanti erga se tanti probo amicum.
  </p>

      Nullum orientis
    </h2>
  

  <p>
    Se dici humanitatem se omnes quis umquam commune pertinent quaedam quadam
    quasi neque quidem ita quasi nos quadam vinculum quasi.
  </p>



  
    <h3>Asperner complectitur</h3>
  

  <p>
    Volo sint petulanter quae ista tantum videbamus te est in possit ulla deinde
    abes invitum a quam omnes verborum voluerunt.
  </p>

document.description: A Rich Text Block contains text that can be styled.
document.name: Rich Text

body.html:
<p>
    Etenim si <b>attendere diligenter</b>, existimare vere <code>de omni hac</code> causa volueritis, sic constituetis, iudices, nec <u>descensurum quemquam</u> ad hanc <i>accusationem</i> fuisse, cui, <s>utrum vellet</s>, liceret, nec.
</p>

<p>
    Nunc <i>vero inanes</i> flatus <u><b>quorundam vile</b></u> esse quicquid extra urbis pomerium <code><u><s>nascitur</s></u></code> aestimant praeter orbos et caelibes, nec <s><i>credi potest</i></s> qua obsequiorum diversitate <u><i><b>coluntur homines sine</b></i></u> liberis <s>Romae</s>.
</p>

<p>
    Et olim licet otiosae sint tribus <b>pacataeque centuriae et nulla suffragiorum certamina set Pompiliani redierit securitas temporis</b>, per omnes tamen quotquot sunt partes terrarum, ut domina suscipitur et regina et <u><s>ubique patrum</s></u> reverenda <u><s><i><b>cum auctoritate</b></i></s></u> canities <i>populique Romani</i> nomen circumspectum et verecundum.
</p>

Etenim si attendere diligenter, existimare vere de omni hac causa volueritis, sic constituetis, iudices, nec descensurum quemquam ad hanc accusationem fuisse, cui, utrum vellet, liceret, nec.

Nunc vero inanes flatus quorundam vile esse quicquid extra urbis pomerium nascitur aestimant praeter orbos et caelibes, nec credi potest qua obsequiorum diversitate coluntur homines sine liberis Romae.

Et olim licet otiosae sint tribus pacataeque centuriae et nulla suffragiorum certamina set Pompiliani redierit securitas temporis, per omnes tamen quotquot sunt partes terrarum, ut domina suscipitur et regina et ubique patrum reverenda cum auctoritate canities populique Romani nomen circumspectum et verecundum.

</p>

Cato ille amice recte sed nec Catone amice ut autem in alia Catone perfecto perfecto fuit memineram spectato perfecto nemo.

By default, mentions simply resolve to plain text. You can easily create your own renderer to show more information about the mentioned user. 

<span>@Martin PAUCOT</span>

document.description:
A code block contains multiple lines of codes.

You can also define the language that can then be used to colorize the code. Check the HLJS Plugin for more information.
document.name: Code

      import { defineDatabase, makeSource } from 'contentlayer-source-notion';
      
      export const Block = defineDatabase(() => ({
        name: 'Block',
        databaseId: '<databaseId>',
      }));

      export default makeSource({
        client,
        renderer,
        databaseTypes: [Block],
      });
      </code>
    </pre>
  Morborum corpus in mundi ad labes capite
</div>

import { defineDatabase, makeSource } from 'contentlayer-source-notion';

export const Block = defineDatabase(() => ({
  name: 'Block',
  databaseId: '',
}));

export default makeSource({
  client,
  renderer,
  databaseTypes: [Block],
});

document.description: Headings are the titles of your page. Notion only provide h1, h2 and h3.
document.name: Headings

body.html:
<h1>
	Congestosque commeatus
</h1>
<h2>
	Taliaque summo

<h1>
	Heading 3
</h1></h2>

Congestosque commeatus

Taliaque summo

Incidisset secum

How it works?

By default the library does not import any styling. Each block is rendered with custom classes prefixed with notion- and followed with the properties of the block (eg. notion-callout) that you can style with your own theme.



Importing Notion Theme

The library is shipped with a theme that tries to replicate the Notion style.

You can simply import it in your app: 

@import "@notion-render/client/sass/index.css";
⚠️
Make sure to wrap rendered content inside a
block.

Paragraphs

In Notion, line breaks result in empty paragraph blocks instead of
. This behaviour could lead into spacing not reflected on your frontend. To avoid this issue, you should add a min-height to your paragraphs: 

p {
	min-height: 2em;
}

Colors

In Notion it is possible to change the color of a block between the following one:

  • Default (means no color)
  • Blue
  • Red
  • Yellow
  • Gray
  • Brown
  • Orange
  • Green
  • Purple
  • Pink
ℹ️
The “Background color” changes the color of the block where the “Color” changes the color of the paragraph.

Introduction

The following guide will teach you the basics of @notion-render/client by walking you through how to render your pages using Next.JS.

ℹ️
If you want to create a full blog, take a look at the Contentlayer Notion Source plugin! This documentation has been made with it.

🔨 Setup the project

Create the Next.JS project

First create a brand new Next.JS project and cd into it: 

$ npx create-next-app notion-render-example
$ cd notion-render-example

As the skeleton contains some styling, delete the content of styles/globals.css

Install dependencies

Install the library and its dependencies: 

$ npm install @notion-render/client @notionhq/client
ℹ️
The @notionhq/client library is the official Notion JS SDK. It is required to render complexe blocks like tables, columns, etc.

Configure the Client and the Renderer

Let’s create an instance of @notionhq/client and @notion-renderer/client in libs/notion.ts that we will use accross our app: 

// libs/notion.ts

import { Client } from "@notionhq/client";
import { NotionRenderer } from "@notion-render/client";

const client = new Client({ auth: process.env.NOTION_TOKEN });
const renderer = new NotionRenderer({ client });

export const notion = {
  client,
  renderer,
};
ℹ️
Follow the guide Create Notion Token to create your own integration and get a NOTION_TOKEN.

🚀 Render your first page

Setup getServerSideProps

In this guide we will create a simple pages/[slug].tsx page where the slug will be the ID of the Notion Page we will render.

In the getServerSideProps function, retreive the slug from the parameters, and use the @notionhq/client instance to get the page blocks.

Transform thoses blocks into HTML and pass it in props. 

// pages/[slug].tsx

import { notion } from "@/libs/notion";
import { BlockObjectResponse } from "@notionhq/client/build/src/api-endpoints";
import { GetServerSideProps, InferGetServerSidePropsType } from "next";

type Data = {
  html: string;
};

export const getServerSideProps: GetServerSideProps<data> = async ({
  params,
}) => {
  if (!params || !params.slug) {
    return {
      notFound: true,
    };
  }

  const blocks = await notion.client.blocks.children
    .list({
      block_id: params.slug as string,
    })
    .then((res) => res.results as BlockObjectResponse[]);

  const html = await notion.renderer.render(...blocks);

  return {
    props: {
      html,
    },
  };
};</data>
⚠️
Notion API can be slow. In production you should avoid Server Side Rendering and use Static Site Generation by using Next.JS features or a tool like Contentlayer.

Rendering the HTML

Now that your HTML is available, you can simply render it: 

export default function Page({
  html,
}: InferGetServerSidePropsType) {
  return (
    <div></div>
  );
}

Visit your page

Run the app by using npm run dev and visit http://localhost:3000/.

Depending on your page content, you should get something like this:

🎨 Styling your page

In our example page we have Headings, Columns, a Callout and a Bookmark but as you can see there is no style yet.

You can use your own style or you can import the theme provided by the library that tries to replicates the Notion design.

In this guide we are going to install Tailwind CSS and import the provided theme.

Install Tailwind CSS

Installing Tailwind for Next.JS is extremely straight forward: 

$ npm install -D tailwindcss postcss autoprefixer
$ npx tailwindcss init -p

Import Tailwind and Notion Theme

In the file styles/globals.css add the following directives to import Tailwind and the provided Notion Theme. 

# styles/globals.css

@import '@notion-render/client/index.css';

@tailwind base;
@tailwind components;
@tailwind utilities;

And Voilà! We have a beautiful Notion styled page!

HLJS plugins uses Highlight.js to colorize your Code blocks.

The purpose of this plugin is to improve your frontend performance by using Highlight.js server side.

Install 

$ npm install @notion-render/hljs-plugin

Usage 

import { NotionRenderer } from '@notion-render/client';
import { Client } from '@notionhq/client';
import hljs from '@notion-render/hljs-plugin';

const client = new Client({ auth: process.env.NOTION_TOKEN });
const renderer = new NotionRenderer({ client });

renderer.use(hljs());

renderer.render(...blocks);

⚠️
Do not forget to import your favorite highlighting style from the 248 availables! More information on the Highlight.JS website!
